thread.title: Grey Whales Are In Vancouver's English Bay Once Again
thread.title_full: Grey Whales Are In Vancouver's English Bay Once Again

author: Rhianna Schmunk
title: Grey Whales Are In Vancouver's English Bay Once Again
text:
Grey Whales Are In Vancouver's English Bay Once Again The Huffington Post B.C. | By Rhianna Schmunk ADVERTISEMENT 
Another day, another grey whale sighting in Vancouver. 
One of the massive animals went cruising through the city's English Bay on Sunday, to the delight of many boaters on the water and a crowd of spectators onshore. 
Johnson Chu was out with the False Creek Rowing Canoe Club and later uploaded a video of the encounter to YouTube. (Watch above.) 
"It was a great ending to our outrigger canoe practice for sure," he told HuffPost B.C. in an email. 
The sighting was one of many in Vancouver over the weekend. 2 of 3. A big thank-you to the guy on the bike who told us about the "whale at English Bay." #greywhale #Vancouver pic.twitter.com/pa0giDsVdW 
— Duncan Minett (@dunkster2112) October 5, 2015 @PacificWhale Another pic of the Grey Whale in #Vancouver yesterday pic.twitter.com/E8COYEO124 
— John E (@jerhardt) September 30, 2015 
Last week, at least one person was compelled to get an even closer look by jumping in the water, prompting the Vancouver Aquarium to issue a public warning on Facebook. 
"Your actions could disrupt natural behaviours such as socializing, resting, and – in this instance – feeding," said the post on Friday. "It’s not just about keeping the whale comfortable and safe, but about doing the same for you." 
It may look tempting, but don’t even think about it. Swimming towards any whale, like this grey whale, is a bad idea... Giant Pacific Octopus Hugs Diver In B.C. of   Canadian biologist Jackie Hildering is using some amazing photos of an encounter between her scuba diving partner, Natasha Dickinson, and a giant octopus to shed light on the sea monster mythology. The inquisitive octopus covered DIckinson's entire face, but neither was in discomfort, said Hildering. Dickinson put her hand over the regulator in her mouth as a precaution, but allowed the curious octopus to explore around her. The octopus also took an interest in a clasp at the end of a bungee cord on Dickinson's gear. NEXT: Seal Tangles With Octopus In Victoria, B.C. A harbour seal was spotted tangling with an octopus in Victoria's Ogden Point on Feb. 9, 2015.  Share
